headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Macy's Third Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to your host Mrs. Karen Hoguet. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to Macy's Third Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to your host Mrs. Karen Hoguet. Please go ahead.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Macy's Calls scheduled to discuss our third quarter earnings with some of our key assumptions for the fourth quarter. I am Karen Hoguet, CFO of the company. Let me start by first apologizing for the confusio
componenttext:
Okay, thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Macy's Calls scheduled to discuss our third quarter earnings with some of our key assumptions for the fourth quarter. I am Karen Hoguet, CFO of the company. 
Let me start by first apologizing for the confusion this morning over the brackets that have mysteriously appeared on our cash flow statement. A business wire is responsible for the problem and frankly, we still haven't figured out quite how it happened, note that a corrected release is now posted on the wire.
On any transcription or other reproduction of the statements made on this call without our consent is prohibited. A replay of the call will be available on our website, www.macysinc.com, beginning approximately 2 hours after the call concludes. Please refer to the Investor Relations section of our website for discussion and reconciliations of any non-GAAP financial measures discussed this morning.
Keep in mind that all forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions mentioned today due to a variety of factors that affect the company, including the risks specified in the company's most recently filed Form 10-K and Form 10-Q.
We are very pleased with our performance in the third quarter. We achieved a 4% comp store gain on top of our 3.9% increase last year. Not only does this represent continued strong absolute performance, but it also compares very favorably to our key competitors. 
We achieved a 64% increase in operating income in the quarter and a 190 basis point improvement in operating income as a percent of sales. Earnings per share were significantly above last year and cash flow generation continued strong. And we feel very prepared for the fourth quarter. 
So I will discuss some of the factors behind this performance, as well as our outlook for the fourth quarter and then as always, we'll open the call for your questions.
Sales in the third quarter were $5,853,000,000, up 4.1% over last year. On comp store basis, sales in the quarter were up 4%, the lower end of our 4% to 4.5% guidance. Our sales exceeded our expectations in August and September, but in October, as you know our sales fell a little short. This can largely be explained by weakness in cold weather merchandise by coates, sweaters and hats gloves and of course, the snow in the North East on that last Saturday of October, obviously hurt us as well. 
We saw the business improved when the weather got colder so we remain optimistic for the fourth quarter. Importantly, we continue to see sales growth at both Macy's and Bloomingdale's in both from stores and online. The fourth quarter merchandising and marketing strategies are terrific and should enable us to achieve our 4% to 4.5% comp store sales growth guidance.
During the third quarter, our Internet businesses continued to perform very well, up 40% over last year. The growth of our omnichannel business is one of the key initiatives driving our success. We believe that the Internet and mobile sites are not only generating great results on their own, but they're also helping us to drive sales into the stores. 
In the third quarter, our strongest geographic region was the Southeast, followed by the Southcentral and Southwest. In addition, poor stores in other regions like Herald Square in New York, State 3 in Water, Chicago, as well as San Francisco did very well. 
Bloomingdale's also had a great third quarter although they too were hurt in October by the warm weather and the snowstorm. 
Our family of business are stronger performances where in men's, cosmetics, handbags and watches. And our weakest sales trends continued in Junior's and casual traditional in Women's apparel. Our home store sales in total were good although not as strong as center core in men's. Within Home, our strongest businesses were textile, furniture and luggage.
In the third quarter, the average unit retail was up 5% with transactions up approximately 1% and units per transaction down approximately 2%, which means the units were down about 1%. 
As you recall, we had expected average unit retail to increase 5% to 7% this fall, with fewer units being sold and we still believe that to be the case. 
At the end of the quarter, inventory in the balance sheet was up 9.6% at the lower end of the 10% to 12% expected range that I had given you during the second quarter earnings call. Remember that we accelerated receipts into October from the 1st week of November, to facilitate the processing of this inventory at our stores. 
And we also accelerated receipts into the first week of all months as we discussed at the end of the second quarter, which increases in transit. That is why though when you look at inventory net of payables, which also adjusts includes the in transit, our inventory net of payables was up only 6%, and excluding both the accelerated receipts and the higher end transit, comp stores would have been up by approximately the same amount as the expected fourth quarter  sales. 
Our stores are more set than ever for the holiday selling and we hope that, that pays off. Remember though that the higher in transit will continue to be a factor at year end and at this point, we expect to end the year with balance sheet inventory up 6% to 7%, the comp store inventory up less than half of that amount.
Gross margin in the third quarter was 39.4%, 60 basis points below last year, which is about what we had expected. This reduction is due to the introduction of free shipping at macys.com and the enormous growth of that business as well as Search and Send from our stores. The merchandise margin was flattish in the third quarter.
SG&A in the quarter was $2,018,000,000 or 2.5% below last year. And as a percent of sales, SG&A was 34.4% or 250 basis points below last year. This is better than we had expected, primarily due to the improved performance of our credit portfolio and to approximately $15 million of timing shifts, primarily in marketing, visual and selling expense from the third quarter in to the fourth quarter. 
Our Credit business generated $108 million more income in the third quarter this year than last year. We had expected improvement as we discussed at the end of the second quarter, but not this much. This relates primarily to significantly lower write-offs. The portfolio has improved faster than we had expected and balances are remaining current are only moving into early ages and not going to write-offs. This is very good news. And we are estimating that the profitability of our credit business this year will actually be higher than that in 2007.
Penetration of our proprietary cards in the third quarter was 48.8%, down 50 basis points from last year. This is due in part to the strength of our 2 stores and in part to a reduction in new accounts. The approval rate of new accounts has declined as we expected because of more stringent ability to pay standards.
Our SG&A would've been pretty much as we expected in total without the great credit performance and the timing shift I just talked about. 
Operating income in the quarter was $291 million, 64% above last year, and 190 basis points as a percent of sales. Interest expense was $108 million in the quarter, down from last year's $164 million. 
Last year, however, did include $39 million related to the early retirement of debt. Without that, last year's interest expense would've been a $125 million. So on that basis, this year our interest expense was $17 million lower. 
Our tax rate in the quarter was 24%. As discussed during the second quarter earnings call, we expected favorable tax settlement in the back half of the year. We had discussed this in August and said at that time they were likely to book in the third quarter, which is in fact what happened. Unfortunately, tax settlements are very hard to predict on a quarterly basis. These settlements were assumed, however, in our guidance of the approximately 37% tax rate for the full year.
Net income in the third quarter was $139 million, average diluted share count was 431.8 million shares for the quarter. 
During the quarter, we bought back 8.2 million shares of stock for approximately $221 million. Earnings per share in the diluted basis in the third quarter was $0.32 versus $0.02 last year or $0.08 per share excluding the comps associated with the debt retirement. Cash flow was strong and net cash provided by operating activity was $627 million versus $346 million last year. And even after the higher CapEx this year, cash flow before financing activities was $94 million more than a year ago. 
We retired $639 million less debt than last year and even after the increase dividend and the buyback, our net cash used year-to-date was $367 million, approximately $600 million better than a year ago. And our credit ratio has also continued to improve with our debt to EBITDA of 2.6 on a rolling 4 quarter basis versus our target of 2.4 to 2.7 and EBITDA of interest of 6.8, which is actually above our target of 6.4 to 6.6. We remain focused on keeping our ratios within our target range in being an investment-grade company.
So with another good quarter, all around, sales, earnings and cash flow, we feel confident that the momentum we have heading into the fourth quarter combined with our holiday strategies bodes well for that quarter. As discussed earlier, we continue to assume comp store sales will be up 4% to 4.5%. The extra day in December before Christmas should not only help December sales relative to November, it should also help the November-December combined time frame overall. 
With that, as our sales assumption, we are assuming EPS of $2.70 to $2.75 for the full year. This is $0.10 better than our prior guidance due to the improved credit performance and a stock buyback. 
And remember, this is $0.45 better than our initial guidance at the beginning of the year of $2.25 to $2.30. This would represent significant growth also over last year's $2.11, excluding asset impairment charges, store closing related costs and the premium on the early retirement of debt. 
For the fourth quarter, this guidance calculates to $1.52 to $1.57.
Based on this assumed performance, our EBITDA as a percent of sales would be close to hitting the 13% mark in 2011. This would represent approximately 70 basis points of improvement over our 2010 EBITDA rate of 12.3%. That is great progress as we make our way to our objective of 14% to 15%. 
Here's a few other comments on our key planning assumptions. One, while we expect our merchandise margin to be flattish in the fourth quarter, our reported gross margin is expected to be down. The decline, however, is expected to be less than that in the third quarter because we will have just about year-round it on the free shipping to the Internet. However, because of the rapid growth in that business, we are expecting it to still negatively impact our gross margin rate.
Two, we are expensing and G&A excluding any asset impairments or store closing costs to be up by less than the comp store sales growth even after that timing shift to be approximately $15 million of marketing visual and selling expense discussed earlier. If we exceeded our sales guidance by the way, the expense increase could be a bit higher. We are investing in our stores to support our MAGIC Selling efforts and we are funding additional resources to help our stores better recover after big days during the holiday season. We also are investing in our omnichannel strategy. Offsetting these investments is an assumption of approximately $55 million to $60 million of improved credit profitability versus last year in the fourth quarter. 
Depreciation and amortization is estimated at approximately $282 million, flat with the third quarter and slightly below last year. Interest expense is assumed to be approximately $107 million in the fourth quarter. And the tax rate is estimated to be approximately 38% in the third quarter, which should result in annual rate of approximately 37% as anticipated all year long. 
Last year, remember they were favorable tax adjustments in the fourth quarter which led to a lower rate, approximately 35%. At last year's tax rate in the fourth quarter been 38%, the EPS would have been $0.07 lower. So keep that in mind as you're comparing our fourth quarter guidance for this year relative to last year.
Also our guidance for the fourth quarter assumes no additional stock buyback. We have said we would buy back some stock prior to the holiday season and not buyback a significant amount until the cash comes in from the holiday sales. 
Also our guidance assumes no cost associated with store closings or asset impairments at year end. Last year, you'll recall that number was approximately $25 million and it is impossible though to estimate what it might be this year since those decisions have not yet been made. And CapEx for the year is still expected to be $800 million.
I'll now related tot eh fourth quarter guidance, I wanted to make sure you also saw our separate release this morning announcing 2 new Macy's stores and one replacement Macy's store. So at this time, we're planning to open to new Macy's next year. Downtime Salt Lake City and Southbridge in Milwaukee. And then for in 2013 or early 2014, Bernie Mills outside of Chicago, Eight Plus in the Bronx, Victorville, California and a replacement store in Bayshore, New York. And for Bloomingdale's, we've announced a new store in Glendale out in Southern California. We are pleased that we're able to identify these great new store opportunities that will further improve our market position and continue to earn terrific returns on invested capital.
All in all, we are pleased to be maintaining the momentum over the past 2 years in sales growth, earnings and cash flow, as well as in gaining market share. The fourth quarter is when retailers like Macy's and Bloomingdale's really shine and take on special meaning to customers. We have great fashions, exceptional gifts, memorable experiences and well-trained associates in our stores and online for shoppers this holiday season. We are all very excited about what the next 3 months will bring. 
And with that, I'll open the call up for your questions.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question with Michelle Clark with MS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question with Michelle Clark with MS.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: So my first question in the third quarter incremental credit improvement of $108 million your fourth quarter outlook calling for improvement of $55 million to $60 million and while certainly positive, a notable slowdown versus 3Q, is there room for upside
componenttext: So my first question in the third quarter incremental credit improvement of $108 million your fourth quarter outlook calling for improvement of $55 million to $60 million and while certainly positive, a notable slowdown versus 3Q, is there room for upside there? Is it conservative? Is that being factored into your outlook? What type of improvement are you assuming in your credit portfolio?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think it's conservative obviously we always hope to do better but I don't think is conservative. The third quarter is larger than you might have expected because the way that profit share works with city that owns our portfolio is that we estimate
componenttext: I don't think it's conservative obviously we always hope to do better but I don't think is conservative. The third quarter is larger than you might have expected because the way that profit share works with city that owns our portfolio is that we estimate for the year and then we have a 3 quarter true up in the third quarter. So part of the reason that number was largely is that it includes 3 quarters of catch-up. So if you really can't look at the third quarter and expect that to be the same in the fourth quarter.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's very helpful. And then can you talk about, Karen, where your bad debt expense is today versus prerecession levels.
componenttext: Got it. That's very helpful. And then can you talk about, Karen, where your bad debt expense is today versus prerecession levels.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our net debt expenses is still a little higher than it was in '07. There's still good to some room to improve as we move into 2012, but the profitability as I said earlier overall is more so largely due to lower funding costs now than in '07.
componenttext: Our net debt expenses is still a little higher than it was in '07. There's still good to some room to improve as we move into 2012, but the profitability as I said earlier overall is more so largely due to lower funding costs now than in '07.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you mentioned your fourth quarter  EPS outlook does not include incremental share buybacks in the fourth quarter. Can just discuss your appetite for buying back in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then you mentioned your fourth quarter  EPS outlook does not include incremental share buybacks in the fourth quarter. Can just discuss your appetite for buying back in the fourth quarter?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I mean we have said that we we're going to buy some back for the holiday season but not a lot which is I think is consistent with what you saw in the third quarter. And so we could buyback a little, but frankly, I think we're going to hold hauled off in a
componenttext: I mean we have said that we we're going to buy some back for the holiday season but not a lot which is I think is consistent with what you saw in the third quarter. And so we could buyback a little, but frankly, I think we're going to hold hauled off in any significant way until we see and have the cash in from the holiday season.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then last question, Karen. If could updates on price optimization what you're seeing there and then the potential impact of topline gross margin?
componenttext: Great. And then last question, Karen. If could updates on price optimization what you're seeing there and then the potential impact of topline gross margin?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we continue to be very excited by the opportunity to price goods scientifically using the system that we're putting into play. I guess as we're going to begin to see some of that benefit about this time next year. We've begun to test it, which is
componenttext: I think we continue to be very excited by the opportunity to price goods scientifically using the system that we're putting into play. I guess as we're going to begin to see some of that benefit about this time next year. We've begun to test it, which is very interesting but it takes a long time. You really have to get through all clearance cycle before you really understand how it's working. So I wouldn't expect it to be meaningful in any way until frankly 2013. But hope to begin to see some impact at this time next year.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Paul Swinand with MorningStar.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Paul Swinand with MorningStar.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Quickly, just a little housekeeping with the tax settlement. Obviously, you've got a 37% rate blended for the full year, is that something that we'll see year after year or is this kind of a onetime year settlement and now it'll go up next year?
componenttext: Quickly, just a little housekeeping with the tax settlement. Obviously, you've got a 37% rate blended for the full year, is that something that we'll see year after year or is this kind of a onetime year settlement and now it'll go up next year?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we're still working on our planning for next year it's certainly our objective to try to stick to the 37% going forward. Now would be the best I can tell you today as we give guidance for 2012 obviously if there's a change, we would update it.
componenttext: Well, we're still working on our planning for next year it's certainly our objective to try to stick to the 37% going forward. Now would be the best I can tell you today as we give guidance for 2012 obviously if there's a change, we would update it.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Just a follow-up question to Michel's on the credit card portfolio, isn't the average customer a little better off since there are maybe fewer people being extended credit? So wouldn't be logical for that the average customer might this be
componenttext: Okay. And then Just a follow-up question to Michel's on the credit card portfolio, isn't the average customer a little better off since there are maybe fewer people being extended credit? So wouldn't be logical for that the average customer might this be a better payer compared to 2007 in general, or you don't want to go that far?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't know that I want to go that far. I mean I can tell you that the bad debt has come down faster than we expected. So about maybe what you're talking about but we still have a little bit of room to go to even get to '07. So again I think this will co
componenttext: I don't know that I want to go that far. I mean I can tell you that the bad debt has come down faster than we expected. So about maybe what you're talking about but we still have a little bit of room to go to even get to '07. So again I think this will continue to some degree in 2012 but nowhere close to the magnitude of we've seen this year.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: But the average quality of each cardholder is probably higher though, right? As you cut out the bottom?
componenttext: But the average quality of each cardholder is probably higher though, right? As you cut out the bottom?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: One would think.
componenttext: One would think.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then question on the Online business, I know we've talked about it before on the call but as you see such strong increase even lapping higher year increases, can you talk about whether it's more of a conversion thing or are you extending reach a
componenttext: Okay. And then question on the Online business, I know we've talked about it before on the call but as you see such strong increase even lapping higher year increases, can you talk about whether it's more of a conversion thing or are you extending reach and frequency of your online advertising to keep those online sales going?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's very interesting, we're finding even with a strong online businesses, our store business is stronger than ever. So there actually working in tandem. A lot of people were worried that it would not be incremental business. But what we're finding i
componenttext: Yes, it's very interesting, we're finding even with a strong online businesses, our store business is stronger than ever. So there actually working in tandem. A lot of people were worried that it would not be incremental business. But what we're finding is that the omnichannel customer spends more with us and some cases here she will be look at something online, try it on the store and sometimes vice versa. Sometimes they'll buy it online and return it in the store buy other things. So it's actually a turning out to be far better in terms of generating sales growth that I think even we thought it would do.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Does the online customer buy as much private and exclusive label or is there different mix online versus?
componenttext: Does the online customer buy as much private and exclusive label or is there different mix online versus?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I've never look at that. It would have to do with what we offer online, but my guess is that similar. We're not finding huge differences if this is your question between our online customer and our in-store customer.
componenttext: I've never look at that. It would have to do with what we offer online, but my guess is that similar. We're not finding huge differences if this is your question between our online customer and our in-store customer.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Karen, just wanted to follow-up on CapEx. I know you confirmed to the $800 million for the year. With the New York flagship renovation coming on, what should we expect the longer-term run rate to look like?
componenttext: Karen, just wanted to follow-up on CapEx. I know you confirmed to the $800 million for the year. With the New York flagship renovation coming on, what should we expect the longer-term run rate to look like?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we think it'll probably be in a range of $800 million to $850 million, we're still working on the specifics for 2012. Obviously, as the EBITDA has increased, we do have more capacity to spend a little bit more. Also with more great new store opportu
componenttext: Well, we think it'll probably be in a range of $800 million to $850 million, we're still working on the specifics for 2012. Obviously, as the EBITDA has increased, we do have more capacity to spend a little bit more. Also with more great new store opportunities, you hate not to do those. I mean it, it's wrong not to if they have good return. So it may go up a little bit not because it's Herald Square but because of other opportunities. In Herald Square we've worked within the $800 million. So next year maybe $850 million, I don't yet we're still working on it. But you see above $900 million, that gives you some range of where we're looking.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: The 5% this quarter and you're still expecting 5% to 7% in the back half. Any categories or can you talk a bit about your experience there, what's been working better or worse?
componenttext: The 5% this quarter and you're still expecting 5% to 7% in the back half. Any categories or can you talk a bit about your experience there, what's been working better or worse?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's interesting. In most cases we've done a pretty good job of predicting the unit sales given the price increases. So it's hard to say there's any one category where we've been wrong, there are programs here and there where we are finding pricing as we
componenttext: It's interesting. In most cases we've done a pretty good job of predicting the unit sales given the price increases. So it's hard to say there's any one category where we've been wrong, there are programs here and there where we are finding pricing as we go. But overall, I think we get a pretty good job on merchants really focused on this of predicting fairly closely. So I can't really tell you there's any categories where we were wrong.

componenttext: Follow-up question, I guess related to what you're talking earlier on share buybacks. Now that you've met your leverage and average target ratios, it seems like you're free cash flow is not going to be deployed towards debt reduction going forward. Can you talk about what you're expecting in terms of free cash flow deployment in 2012 and beyond, is that something the Board's going to decide on at the end of the fiscal year?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is something we look at once we see how this year ends. But clearly, with our credit ratio where they are, there will be much more cash being used for things like buy back or the dividend or those kinds of uses. But also, I expect we'll  continu
componenttext: Yes, this is something we look at once we see how this year ends. But clearly, with our credit ratio where they are, there will be much more cash being used for things like buy back or the dividend or those kinds of uses. But also, I expect we'll  continue to reduce debt also, just not with 100% of the cash flow going to debt. But I think we'll continue to be balanced as we have always said we would be.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011

componenttext: Okay, so as we look at some debt maturities in 2012, we could see some of that being refinanced, but maybe some of the paydown as well?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's fair.
componenttext: Yes, I think that's fair.

componenttext: So as we think about Holiday 2011 and I think there's some discussion about some marketing visual and selling expense ship. headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011

componenttext: I think it's just even better refined way of approaching the business that we did last year. I think the My Macy's impact on holiday is far greater this year than it was last year. So I think you're  going to see better assortments in all of our doors, which I think will be very exciting. And we learned a lot last year and hopefully make those adjustments and we'll have a spectacular Christmas.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And I don't  know if you can talk about I know performance of the Bloomingdale's outlets and then also with the Green Mills Macy's store, will that be the first full price store in an outlet center?
componenttext: Great. And I don't  know if you can talk about I know performance of the Bloomingdale's outlets and then also with the Green Mills Macy's store, will that be the first full price store in an outlet center?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, first on the Bloomingdale's outlet, that's performing well, some better than others but we feel good about their performance and then there will be more new outlets announced for next year, we just don't have the deals competed yet. But we're going t
componenttext: Yes, first on the Bloomingdale's outlet, that's performing well, some better than others but we feel good about their performance and then there will be more new outlets announced for next year, we just don't have the deals competed yet. But we're going to continue to expand that into '12 as well. As the Mills, it is our first time we're going to have a full line regular Macy's store in an outlet or a mixed-use center, and2 were actually quite excited by it. If it works it, obviously, opens up lot more opportunities for stores like that. So we'll see.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as it relates to gross margin time, I mean you had a flat merchandise margin in the quarter and it sounds like that's how you're planning for the fourth quarter. Maybe you could help to sort of characterize what you see out there, obviously
componenttext: Okay. And then as it relates to gross margin time, I mean you had a flat merchandise margin in the quarter and it sounds like that's how you're planning for the fourth quarter. Maybe you could help to sort of characterize what you see out there, obviously you're opening earlier for Black Friday, others started to jump on the bandwagon, just give us your assessment. We know holidays always promotional, but how you compare this year to past, preview seasons?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Holiday periods are always promotional. I don't think any of us can make them more so because I don't think you can find a day between now and January to act. So by the way, planned promotion tends to be profitable. It's only when inventory is out of line
componenttext: Holiday periods are always promotional. I don't think any of us can make them more so because I don't think you can find a day between now and January to act. So by the way, planned promotion tends to be profitable. It's only when inventory is out of line with sales which in our case is not the case where you get excessive of markdowns and margin it's. But in terms of promotions, but I think it's going to be pretty much half it's been the last couple of years, which is very heavy. But again, plant promotions are not unprofitable.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, for you not so much for Others. And then just following on the margins topic, it sounds like the fourth quarter there's some easing on the pressure you lap free shipping year-over-year. But the ramp in that channel it sounds like that will continue
componenttext: Sure, for you not so much for Others. And then just following on the margins topic, it sounds like the fourth quarter there's some easing on the pressure you lap free shipping year-over-year. But the ramp in that channel it sounds like that will continue to be a pressure on margins. How to think about how that channel continues to grow, how should we think about gross margins next year as we think about free shipping you will fully anniversary it, does headwind completely go away is that channel continues to grow in penetration?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, the headwind will not go away. But again what you all should focus on is a profitability of the omnichannel business in total the EBIT or the operating income not just the gross margin. Sort of an oddity of GAAP accounting in my opinion that it ends u
componenttext: No, the headwind will not go away. But again what you all should focus on is a profitability of the omnichannel business in total the EBIT or the operating income not just the gross margin. Sort of an oddity of GAAP accounting in my opinion that it ends up in margin, that's a different issue. But there's been a lot of noise about the drain of profitability because the growth of free shipping that's not the case. The shift where it is on the P&L.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011

componenttext: Well, it's one of those things, Jeff, that's really hard to quantify. Somewhat argue with the more profitable online that in the stores. I would argue perhaps we have an allocated marketing expense properly when we look at it that way. So I would say today the online businesses is more profitable, but again, if you fully allocate it expense, I'm not sure. But it certainly is not less profitable.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Honestly, and again, it's early to talk about next year because I look now our merchandise margins are flattish, which is sort of what I've been telling people to project going forward for us, there's lot of good things, there's a lot of bad things and we
componenttext: Honestly, and again, it's early to talk about next year because I look now our merchandise margins are flattish, which is sort of what I've been telling people to project going forward for us, there's lot of good things, there's a lot of bad things and we've got the hit gross margin on top of the merchandise results from the free shipping. So we give guidance after the end of the year, we'll obviously do what we can to be helpful. But I would expect gross margin, merchandise margins to be flattish and there will be the continued headwind from the free shipping.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And how does the cost environment factor into your merchandise margin assumptions?
componenttext: And how does the cost environment factor into your merchandise margin assumptions?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: That is one of the factors we're dealing with. I think our merchants did a really good job of trying to merchandise around the cost increases and where they could hold onto their margins or in some cases take more than they did. Other places with greater
componenttext: That is one of the factors we're dealing with. I think our merchants did a really good job of trying to merchandise around the cost increases and where they could hold onto their margins or in some cases take more than they did. Other places with greater price sensitivity, so a little hit on margin but again it all balanced in the mix. This is when having an experienced organization like we do really helps.

componenttext: Just on the omnichannel, at what point do you think your brick-and-mortar inventory system and your Internet inventory systems will be able to speak to one another chain-wide and effectively allow you to site to store to door nationwide, somewhat Nordstrom did a couple of years ago.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're going to be able to do with very soon. We're testing it right now and early next year, I think we're going to use do it more and more. We have the systems we have today, having said that, we are going to invest over time in better systems that allow
componenttext: We're going to be able to do with very soon. We're testing it right now and early next year, I think we're going to use do it more and more. We have the systems we have today, having said that, we are going to invest over time in better systems that allow us to maximize the inventory easier. That is much manual intervention, but it's not going to prevent us from doing the Site to Store door.

componenttext: That's obviously our trough point. We're still working on those plans. For this year, obviously, we did not want to borrow from the working capital facility. I suspect we'll keep that guard rail in the future, but I don't know yet. So we'll have to see.

componenttext: Karen, as we look at the fourth quarter and next year, can you speak did areas of opportunity on the top line, how should we think about drivers online, Bloomingdale's, MAGIC Selling , omnichannel looking forward, curious how we should think about these drivers in terms of breaking down the overall comp and what your level of excitement toward each of these is going forward.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't know how to help you quantify each one of the strategies because they are also interrelated. But clearly, we feel extremely excited about all 3 of our major strategies, My Macy's which I think we continue to improve and get better at. Omnich
componenttext: Well, I don't know how to help you quantify each one of the strategies because they are also interrelated. But clearly, we feel extremely excited about all 3 of our major strategies, My Macy's which I think we continue to improve and get better at. Omnichannel, which we've been talking about this morning and MAGIC Selling where the cultures is just building our Net Promoter Scores are increasing significantly and we think that's going to help sales a lot as we move into next year. So I would say we're equally excited about all 3 and we think it will be very helpful as we get beyond 2011 to continue the sales growth at good levels.

componenttext: I don't think so. I think it's going to be other than perhaps the management change at everything feels pretty much as it would have felt a year ago.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question just the kind of touch on Chuck mentioned, the consumer behavior as you're seeing in your stores over the past few months, are you seeing anything from your higher-end customers versus the lower end demographics and along thos
componenttext: Okay. And then last question just the kind of touch on Chuck mentioned, the consumer behavior as you're seeing in your stores over the past few months, are you seeing anything from your higher-end customers versus the lower end demographics and along those the same lines, anything in a category specific more discretionary areas such as home, any changes of note?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: We really haven't seen any changes. What we have been saying is that we do see in the world that the lower income customer is struggling more than the middle or upper end customer and I think that's continuing. But I wouldn't say it's impacting anything d
componenttext: We really haven't seen any changes. What we have been saying is that we do see in the world that the lower income customer is struggling more than the middle or upper end customer and I think that's continuing. But I wouldn't say it's impacting anything differently now that it did a couple of months ago and not anything that we're seeing necessarily category by category.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess some questions about the renovation. During the renovation, are you expecting any sales disruption? And then as you look out at your fleet in general, are you sort of happy with how the stores look and feel, can you give us any sort of updated tho
componenttext: I guess some questions about the renovation. During the renovation, are you expecting any sales disruption? And then as you look out at your fleet in general, are you sort of happy with how the stores look and feel, can you give us any sort of updated thoughts on when certain number of stores has been touched, just go through that at one point in time talk about like 75% of the stores have been refreshed or anything like that we could know about the fleet?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, on Herald Square, we do expect there to be some disruption next year, but we would still expect the store to grow year-over-year and we're still obviously quantifying the details there. I think it's also important to say that the renovation of Hera
componenttext: First, on Herald Square, we do expect there to be some disruption next year, but we would still expect the store to grow year-over-year and we're still obviously quantifying the details there. I think it's also important to say that the renovation of Herald Square is not coming at the expense of maintaining the rest of the stores. So we are continuing to invest to try to maintain the fleet feet as you called it. Year-by-year, we typically touch 40 to 50 stores a year and that will continue. '08, '09 was a little less than that as you might expect as we have s brought the capital down but we're back up to that level and I think that feels about right, but we'll continue to do that.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess Karen as you look at '12 given the credit results from this year, overall, for the full year, would you think credit will be continue to be a tailwind or do you think it will be a headwind given some of the especially the third quarter and what yo
componenttext: I guess Karen as you look at '12 given the credit results from this year, overall, for the full year, would you think credit will be continue to be a tailwind or do you think it will be a headwind given some of the especially the third quarter and what you're seeing.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: As I said, we're still looking at 2012, but I don't expect it to be a headwind. I don't think we'll get the improvement again because as I said we're already going to be more profitable this year than in 2007, but I think it will continue to be accretive
componenttext: As I said, we're still looking at 2012, but I don't expect it to be a headwind. I don't think we'll get the improvement again because as I said we're already going to be more profitable this year than in 2007, but I think it will continue to be accretive operating income next year in terms of growth. But again, no we're close to the magnitude. Now that's for the full year. By quarter,, it may be quirky. So when we give guidance, we'll obviously update you because as I explained in the third quarter, we had a bit of a catch up for the first 2 quarters so it may be the next year or the third quarter. The income by quarter may be different, but we'll update you when we give guidance for 2012.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011

componenttext: And just following on the Herald Square remodel, the ROI for the company, would you expect that to be impacted major league from the Herald Square remodel? How should we think about that?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me be clear, we would not be doing the Herald Square remodel that didn't exceed our internal rate of return and RIC. So it will be accretive to our hurdle rates in cost of capital.
componenttext: Let me be clear, we would not be doing the Herald Square remodel that didn't exceed our internal rate of return and RIC. So it will be accretive to our hurdle rates in cost of capital.

componenttext: It's part of our business. We manage the totality and we are very involved in the management of the credit business and it's not something I just sort of push aside. componenttext: We did not see an opportunity, let me start there. headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: The new accounts that were down in the third quarter and it's primarily driven by the approval rate being worse than a year ago, which is actually what we had expected to have happened because at point of sale we're having to ask not only for income infor
componenttext: The new accounts that were down in the third quarter and it's primarily driven by the approval rate being worse than a year ago, which is actually what we had expected to have happened because at point of sale we're having to ask not only for income information but also housing information. But we're finding is we started referring more customers at point of sale into our credit granting group, just to make sure they understand what they're being asked and that they entered information correctly. And so what are finding in fact is that people are making mistakes, they're entering this information. So we hope we'll  be able to improve on these statistics as we go forward.
